content.webTitle: Phil Daoust: Radio pick of the day

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.bodyText: You can tell a lot from someone's hair, and not just how often they wash. As it grows - at a rate of about a centimetre a month - it locks in information about your diet, environment and lifestyle. At Bradford university, archaeologist Andrew Wilson is using these "biochemical signatures" to find out what our ancestors ate and what sent them to the great barber's in the sky, while at Glamorgan, forensic scientist Richard Paul is getting disturbing insights into the living's drinking habits. They tell Quentin Cooper all about it in The Material World (4.30pm, Radio 4). Ian Sampson, meanwhile, is telling the story of Arthur Mee, who left school at 14 but went on to educate millions of kids as editor of the Children's Encyclopaedia and the Children's Newspaper. He was not a man who believed in writer's block, averaging a million words a year and bashing out a dazzling array of books on travel, general knowledge and British history. Artist Grayson Perry, astronomer Heather Couper and publisher Steve Rudd sing his praises in Arthur Mee: Encylopaedist (11.30am, Radio 4).
